array.string: New Orleans falls to Union forces.
Union troops officially take possession of New Orleans, completing the occupation that had begun four days earlier.
General Robert E. Lee leads 55,000 men across the Potomac River and they enter Maryland.
The 54th's 1,007 black soldiers and 37 white officers gathered in the Boston Common and prepared to head to the battlefields of the South.

The battle of Fort Pillow ended with a massacre of African-American Union troops and their white officers attempting to surrender, by soldiers under the command of Confederate Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest.
The city fell, after a Union siege and various attempts to seize railroads and supply lines leading to Atlanta. After taking the city, Sherman's troops headed south-southeastward.
Robert E. Lee becomes General in Chief of the Armies of the Confederate States
